choices.text: The functioning unit is the lobule supplied by a single arteriole and consists of 24-40 follicles lined with cuboidal epithelium
The left recurrent laryngeal nerve runs more obliquely to reach the tracheo esophageal groove
Approximately 2 % of nerves on the right side are non recurrent and will enter the larynx from above

questions.text: A 20 years old female patient was presented to opd with the butterfly shaped swelling infront of the neck. All of the following facts are true about this gland except ?
questions.solution:
Option A :

  • The normal thyroid gland weighs 20-25 g
  • The functioning unit is the lobule supplied by a single arteriole and consists of 24-40 follicles lined with cuboidal epithelium. The follicle contains colloid in which thyroglobulin is stored.

Option B :

  • A branch of the vagus, the nerve recurs round the arch of the aorta on the left and the subclavian artery on the right.
  • The clinical significance of this is that on the left the nerve has more distance in which to reach the tracheo-oesophageal groove and therefore runs in a medial plane.
  • On the right, there is less distance and the nerve runs more obliquely to reach the tracheo-oesophageal groove.

Option C :

  • Approximately 2% of nerves on the right are non-recurrent and will enter the larynx from above.

Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery; 28th edition; chapter 55; page number :850, 851.

questions.text: A 56 years old male patient was presented in opd with a complaint of swelling in front of neck. On examination and further investigation it was isolated cystic swelling. Risk of malignancy in this patient was?
questions.solution: Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery; 28th edition; chapter 55; page number:858.

questions.text: A 34 year old male patient was brought to emergency with severe upper abdominal pain for the last 24 hours. On further evaluation he was diagnosed as a case of acute pancreatitis. His serum calcium and parathormone levels were raised. Ultrasound of the neck was performed which was normal but MIBI scan was suggestive of parathyroid adenoma. What should be the next step in management of this patient ?
questions.solution:
In this case there is discordance between MIBI and Ultrasound.

  • Multiphase CT imaging (4D-CT) has become widely utilized to localise disease.It gives both anatomical and functional information about the parathyroid glands.
  • Using precontrast, postcontrast and delayed images, it demonstrates not only detailed anatomical localisation but, combined with rapid uptake and washout, allows hyperfunctioning glands to be differentiated from lymph nodes that demonstrate a progressive enhancement pattern.
  • The potential disadvantage of 4D-CT scanning is the higher radiation dose when compared with traditional imaging modalities.

Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery; 28th edition; chapter 55; page number :879.

questions.text: A 25 years old male patient was operated case of parathyroidectomy of all 4 glands with auto transplantation in the left forearm. Permanent hypoparathyroidism is defined as the continuing need for calcium and / or vitamin D replacement at ________ months postoperatively in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Permanent hypoparathyroidism is defined as the continuing need for calcium and/or vitamin D replacement at 1 year postoperatively.
  • Symptoms include mild circumoral or digital numbness and paraesthesia, carpo-pedal or laryngeal spasms and cardiac arrhythmias.
  • Chvostek’s sign refers to contraction of the ipsilateral facial muscles on percussion of the facial nerve below the zygoma.
  • Trousseau’s sign refers to the development of carpopedal spasm secondary to occlusion of the arm (usually with a blood pressure cuff).
  • Biochemical investigations include total and ionised calcium levels as well as serum magnesium levels. An ECG may demonstrate a prolonged QT interval or QRS complex changes.
  • Mild hypocalcaemia can be treated with oral calcium and vitamin D supplementation.
  • Acute symptomatic hypocalcaemia is an emergency and should be corrected with intravenous as well as oral calcium and vitamin D replacement.
  • Traditionally, 10 mL of 10% calcium gluconate is administered slowly intravenously. *Supplemental magnesium may also be required, owing to the synergistic action of transporters for calcium and magnesium.
  • Clinical features of hypocalcemia

SPASMODIC

S - Spasm

P - Perioral paraesthesia

A - Anxious, irritable

S - Seizures

M - Muscle tone increased (Smooth muscles)

O- Orientation impaired and confusion

D - Dermatitis

I - Impetigo herpetiformis (Rare and serious)

C - Chvostek's sign

Cardiomyopathy (long QT interval on ECG)

Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery; 28th edition; chapter 56; page number :881.

questions.text: Adrenal cortex has three different zones which secrete different steroid. Match the following for adrenal glands correctly
questions.solution:
• The adrenal cortex represents 90% of the gland and is arranged in a zonal configuration guration.


Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery; 28th edition; chapter 57; page number :889.

questions.text: A 40 yrs old female patient presented to opd with the appearance of lemon on sticks. Which clinical feature has the highest incidence in this patient ?
questions.solution:
• Because of the pleiotropic actions of cortisol, the clinical features of Cushing’s syndrome are broad and multisystem.
  • The typical patient is characterized by a facial plethora, a buffalo hump and a moon face in combination with hypertension, diabetes, central obesity and proximal muscle-wasting, traditionally referred to as the 'lemon on sticks' appearance.

Remember : Cushing disease occurs when Cushing syndrome is caused by an ACTH-producing pituitary tumor, whereas Cushing syndrome is the set of symptoms that results when there is a surplus of cortisol in the body.



Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery; 28th edition; chapter 57; page number :893.

questions.text: A 56 years old female was diagnosed as a case of ductal carcinoma in situ. If features of atypical ductal hyperplasia are seen to involve more than __________ ducts or lesions measure more than _______ in diameter, the term ductal carcinoma in situ is used ?
questions.solution:
• Hyperplasia of the epithelium is defined as the presence of more than two layers of cells in the lining of the ducts and acini. It may occur with or without atypia.
  • If atypia of epithelial cells is seen, the terms atypical ductal hyperplasia (ADH) and atypical lobular hyperplasia (ALH) are used.
  • If features of ADH are seen to involve more than two ducts or lesions measuring >2 mm in diameter, the term ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) is used.

Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery; 28th edition; chapter 58; page number 919

choices.text: It is also known as cystosarcoma phyllodes
Overlying skin is ulcerated due to infiltration of the skin by lesion in early phase
It is true mixed neoplasm comprising both epithelial and mesenchymal elements
Treatment is by wide local excision with a 2 cm margin along with overlying skin and underlying muscle

questions.text: A 35 years old female patient presented to opd with the complaint of a left breast lump since last 6 months. Her clinical photograph is given below. All of the following statements are true about this condition except________?
questions.solution:
• Previously known as cystosarcoma phyllodes, these benign tumours usually occur in women over the age of 30 years.
  • it presents as a large, sometimes massive, tumour with an unevenly bosselated surface
  • The overlying skin is ulcerated owing to pressure necrosis.
  • Despite their size, phyllodes tumours remain mobile on the chest wall and rarely infiltrate the skin until late.
  • It is a true mixed neoplasm comprising both epithelial and mesenchymal elements and resembling a fibroadenoma.
  • Treatment is by wide local excision (WLE) with a 2-cm margin along with the overlying skin and underlying pectoralis major muscle because of a high incidence of local recurrence

Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery; 28th edition; chapter 58; page number :922

choices.text: She is the case of Poland syndrome
She had congenital absence of the left breast but underlying muscles and chest wall are normal

questions.text: A 20 years old female patient was brought to opd with the complaint of absence of the left side of breast.Her clinical photograph is given below. All of the following statements are true about this condition except ?
questions.solution:
• Congenital absence of the breast may occur on one or both sides.
  • It is sometimes associated with Poland’s syndrome, which is characterised by the absence of the sternal portion of the pectoralis major and short webbed fingers (symbrachydactyly) on the side of the involved breast.
  • The breast may be reconstructed with a latissimus dorsi muscle flap and a silicone breast implant

Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery; 28th edition; chapter 58; page number :925,926

questions.text: Mastitis of infants may occur in both boys and girls. It is uncommon and is predominantly caused by ?
questions.solution:
• Mastitis of infants may occur in both boys and girls.
  • It is uncommon and is predominantly caused by Staphylococcus aureus.

Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery; 28th edition; chapter 58; page number :926

choices.text: A 62 years old postmenopausal female patient with inflammatory breast cancer
A 45 years old smoker, female with lump involving chest wall
A 50 years old female with 2 cm lump in upper outer quadrant of left breast with previous history of burns over left breast

questions.text: Sentinel lymph node biopsy is contraindicated in all of the following patients except?
questions.solution:
• The sentinel lymph node refers to the first lymph node in the axilla draining the breast. The sentinel lymph node is identified by the injection of a blue dye (patent blue or methylene blue) and radioisotope technetium-99m-labelled albumin/ sulphur colloid/antimony in the breast.

SLNB is contraindicated in patients with

  • inflammatory breast cancer
  • T4 disease
  • a history of previous breast or chest wall surgery
  • breast scarring (burns) or radiotherapy.

Above mentioned all the cases were contraindicated for SLNB.

Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery; 28th edition; chapter 58; page number 937.

choices.text: a- lateral ventricle; b - foramen of monro; c - third ventricle; d - cerebral aqueduct; e - fourth ventricle
a - fourth ventricle; b - cerebral aqueduct; c - third ventricle; d - foramen of Monro; e - lateral ventricle
a - third ventricle; b - foramen of monro; c - cerebral aqueduct; d - fourth ventricle; e - lateral ventricle
a - foramen of monro; b - third ventricle; c - cerebral aqueduct; d - lateral ventricle; e - fourth ventricle

questions.text: Match the following correctly for anatomy of 'CSF PATHWAY'
questions.solution:
• CSF flows from the lateral ventricles through the foramen of Monro to the third ventricle, then down the cerebral aqueduct to the fourth ventricle, where it exits to the subarachnoid space via the midline foramen of Magendie and the lateral foramina of Luschka.CSF is reabsorbed into the arachnoid villi along the superior sagittal sinus.

Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery; 28th edition; chapter 48; page number :703

questions.text: All of the following genetic disorders are known to predispose patients to the condition seen in the below NCCT BRAIN image in the patient with a history of thunderclap headache which is both sudden and severe and is outside the patient's normal experience except?
questions.solution:
• This is a case of sub arachnoid hemorrhage.
  • The typical presentation of an SAH includes a 'thunderclap' headache, which is both sudden and severe and is outside the patient's normal experience.
  • Some patients describe prodromal headaches preceding the event, potentially representing aneurysm growth or subclinical bleeds. The sudden onset occurs commonly but not exclusively during exertion, and may be associated with seizure (10%), unresponsiveness (50%) and vomiting (70%).
  • Risk factors include age, female sex, hypertension, smoking, cocaine abuse and a family history with two first-degree relatives affected.
  • A range of genetic disorders, in particular adult polycystic kidney disease, fibromuscular dysplasia, neurofibromatosis type 1, Ehlers-Danlos and Marfan syndrome, are known to predispose patients to this condition.

Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery; 28th edition; chapter 48; page number :709

questions.text: Identity the pathology seen in the below specimen
questions.solution:
• GLIOBLASTOMA MULTIFORME - WHO grade IV Tumour commonest glial tumour seen in 5th and 6th decade of life
  • Investigation of choice : MRI of head with and without contrast
  • additional investigation : CT of chest, abdomen and pelvis to exclude extra cranial primary
  • Main Differential diagnosis : METASTASIS
  • Diffusion weighted MRI sequences are valuable to differentiate it from brain abscess.
  • Initial management : STEROID
  • 1st line adjuvant treatment in malignant glioma : High dose focused radiation therapy and alkylating chemotherapy with oral temozolomide.
  • median survival for glioblastoma : 12 months

Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery; 28th edition; chapter 48; page number :715

questions.text: The following incision seen in the image is used in malignancy of ?
questions.solution:
Owing to anatomical differences such as thinner bone, the presence of sinuses, tightly adherent palatal mucosa and proximity to the orbit and skull base, maxillary resection considerations differ from those in the mandible. Small tumours of the maxillary alveolus can be managed by transoral partial maxillectomy.

More extensive tumours involving the floor of the maxillary sinus require wider access by a Weber-Fergusson incision


Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery; 28th edition; chapter 53; page number :822

questions.text: A 6 months old boy was brought to opd with congenital Hydrocele. Surgery is rarely indicated before _______ years because a majority resolve.?
questions.solution:
• A hydrocele is a fluid collection between the parietal and visceral layers of the tunica vaginalis and is usually confined to the scrotum - one can feel the cord above it.
  • Occasionally, it extends into the external ring and one cannot feel the cord. Hydroceles are typically asymptomatic, non-tender and may fluctuate, reducing overnight; they can be bilateral.
  • Infant hydroceles can be tense and uncomfortable, especially if over-examined, causing confusion with an incarcerated inguinal hernia.
  • Although hydroceles transilluminate, this is a flawed test for distinguishing one from an incarcerated inguinal hernia since light easily shines through an infant's intestine.
  • Surgery is rarely indicated before 2 years because a majority resolve. Occasionally an encysted hydrocele of the cord (or hydrocele of the canal of Nuck in a girl) forms as the processus obliterates; persistence warrants exploration.

Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery; 28th edition; chapter 17; page number :257.

questions.text: A 16 years old male patient was operated for inguinal exploration for right testicular pain. Intra operative photograph is given below. In this condition exploration within __________ hours of the onset of symptoms improves the chances of testicular salvage?
questions.solution:
• Intravaginal (bell clapper) testicular torsion is well recognised in adolescents but may occur at any age. Abnormal posterior anchoring of the testis allows torsion within the tunica vaginalis.
  • Torsion compromises blood flow, causing acute scrotal or abdominal/groin pain, nausea and vomiting.
  • Tenderness, an absent cremasteric reflex and a high testis may be found on examination; oedema and erythema appear later.
  • Sometimes there have been transient episodes (intermittent torsion).
  • Doppler ultrasound may help.
  • Exploration within 6-8 hours of the onset of symptoms improves the chances of testicular salvage.

Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery; 28th edition; chapter 17; page number :258.

questions.text: Expand the CHARGE syndrome.
questions.solution:
• VACTERL syndrome
    • V vertebral,
    • A anorectal,
    • C cardiac,
    • T tracheoesophageal,
    • R renal and
    • L limb anomalies
  • CHARGE syndrome
    • C coloboma,
    • H heart defects,
    • C choanal atresia,
    • G growth retardation,
    • G genital anomalies and
    • E ear anomalies

Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery; 28th edition; chapter 18; page number 264.

questions.text: A new born child was brought to opd with abdominal distension and vomiting. Her x ray findings are given below. Operation of choice for this condition is ?
questions.solution:
• X ray here shows double bubble sign due to duodenal atresia

Option A : Ramstedt's pyloromyotomy is the operation done in infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis.


Single bubble seen in pyloric stenosis


Ramstedt's pyloromyotomy

Option B : Duodenal Atresia (D' s of DA are given below)

  • Distal to ampulla of Vater →; bilious vomiting
  • Double bubble sign
  • Deformity like wind shock (duodenal web)
  • Duodenoduodenostomy (kimura's operation)

Option C : LADD'S procedure is used for malrotation.


Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery; 28th edition; chapter 17, 18; page number :266, 267
